A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.
A field homomorphism \\(\sigma: L \longrightarrow L'\\) between two field extensions \\(L / K\\) and \\(L' / K\\) is called a \\(K\\)-homomorphism if it restricts to the identity map on \\(K\\).
Does the concept of a/an Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an K-homomorphism to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To determine if the concept of a Ring is necessary for the definition of a K-homomorphism to make sense, we need to analyze the components involved in the definition of a K-homomorphism. A K-homomorphism is defined as a field homomorphism between two field extensions L/K and L'/K that restricts to the identity map on K. A field, by definition, is a special type of ring that is commutative, has a multiplicative identity, and every non-zero element has a multiplicative inverse. Therefore, the concept of a field inherently includes the properties of a ring. Since a K-homomorphism involves fields, and fields are a subset of rings, understanding the properties and structure of rings is essential to grasp the concept of fields. Consequently, the concept of a ring is necessary to fully understand and define what a field is, and thus, is indirectly required to define a K-homomorphism, which operates on fields.
